bestBHT.bht: At the last time, there shall be scoffers, men who sport with what is holy and good, walking according to their own lusts of impieties. These mockers, in their inebriated state of contempt for God, rush headlong into a brutal rejection of the Divine Being. They reject all that is Divine and exhibit aggravated immorality as a result. This is a characteristic quality demonstrated by those who reject the message of the Second Coming of the Lord, casting off every fear and mocking the doctrine of true religion.

Henry Alford: Hence we see that they to whom Jude is writing, had heard the other Apostles also.
That at the last of the time there shall be scoffers, men who sport with what is holy and good.
Walking according to their own lusts of impieties, indicating the direction, or perhaps the character of those desires.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: The word is found nowhere else in the New Testament.
How Alford can deny that... is referred to (at least in part), I cannot imagine.
Jude quotes the very words of Peter as the words which the apostles used to speak to his (Jude’s) readers.
Marvin Vincent: Ungodly lusts [επιθυμιας των ασεβειων] . Lit., lusts of ungodlinesses.
John Calvin: By the last time he means that in which the renewed condition of the Church received a fixed form till the end of the world; and it began at the first coming of Christ.
He calls them scoffers who, being inebriated with a profane and impious contempt of God, rush headlong into a brutal contempt of the Divine Being.
The world is full of Epicurean despisers of God, who having cast off every fear, madly scoff at the whole doctrine of true religion, regarding it as fabulous.
Philip Schaff: They show their quality in relation to the Second Coming of the Lord.
Every lust rejecting the Divine that is opposed to it, and the rejection of what is Divine ending ever in aggravated immorality.
The expression here used is no doubt intended to call up the characteristic quality already described.
Archibald T. Robertson: How that (οτ). Declarative οτ as in verse Jude 1:5. See discussion of 2 Peter 3:3 for differences, no εν εμπαιγμονη here and no των ασεβειων there.
John Gill: How that they told you that there should be mockers in the last time,.... :-.
